content.rendered:
A lot of pretty, spare, and nicely produced identities this week, with work from Graz, London, and Gdynia.

Bruch by Bruch

Bruch is a graphic design firm in Graz, Austria and the design of their own identity references their name, that more or less translates as “breaking/rupturing”. The identity is a collection of broken bits and pieces that make the individual applications seem random on their own but, as a whole, the elements create a consistent, abstract visual language. There is no broad narrative story to tell nor concept to specifically sell other than “we can design cool stuff” — which they do, if you look at their projects and, to boot, the projects fit the aesthetic of their identity. The applications are like professional-level design exercises of shape and form and they are a joy to see. The bold serif wordmark provides a great contrast to the spare layouts and geometric objects. See full project

Union Hand-Roasted Coffee by Studio Output

Union Hand-Roasted Coffee is an East London coffee roaster selling their batches directly to delis, coffee bars, and restaurants or providing them to catering services. One thing they understand besides coffee is good design, as their previous packaging was pretty good but perhaps a little dark and clinical. The new look by London-based Studio Output is much softer and coffee-er. The element I like the most is the “u” with a coffee cup handle and also its monogram version where the underline of the wordmark becomes a tiny plate. It’s cute, smart, and still looks like it means business. The new packaging is all about the combination of materials and layering that assemble into a nicely crafted piece. See full project

Motiv Studio by Negation Studio

Motiv Studio is a 3D architectural visualization company based in Gdansk, Poland, and Negation Studio, based in neighboring Gdynia, designed a logo that’s a 2D visualization of a 3D idea. The “M” monogram is a great, energetic drawing that wraps a ribbon in and around a hexagon achieving depth in 2D in a simple, elegant way. It’s a really great mark. What attracted me to this project in the first place was that it’s literally a shiny object (and full of other shiny objects). Reproduced in copper ink with copper edging on the business cards and photographed on top of copper plumbing, this was too hard to ignore. I’m not convinced the sans serif typeface works to use it on everything across all materials as there is no point of contrast with the logo but, still, copper. See full project
